Subject: Re: [junit] Auto-generating AllTests.java for each package?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=231973488

I've not noticed Eclipse skipping TestCases before, assuming that the 
convention you use to declare your test cases prevents TestRunner from 
building the relevant TestSuite. Could you be more specific?

--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Jason Rogers wrote:
> On 12/19/2005 03:32 AM, Ilja Preuss apparently said:
> 
>> What development tools are you using? Both Eclipse and Ant, for example,
>> already have built in the feature to gather and run all the tests in a
>> package/directory.
> 
> 1. We don't use Ant to run tests
> 2. reasons we don't use Eclipse's built-in functionality:
>   a. Eclipse seemed to skip some tests in the 3.0.x branch (we would 
> select 1 project whose tests would number N, its dependent projects 
> would weigh in at M tests.  So you would expect N + M tests to have been 
> run.  Not so.  It was N + M - X tests.  I don't know where things were 
> getting lost.  I noticed this because I had a test in which I was 
> forcing a failure and it never failed.  Why?  It never ran.)
>   b. using JUnit-Addons we actually are able to be more selective in the 
> types of tests we run through Eclipse Launchers.  We have launchers for 
> Units only, Units and Database Tests, Functional Tests, and All Tests.  
> The suite is built on the fly via tests implementing specific interfaces.
>
subject: Re: [junit] Auto-generating AllTests.java for each package?
